title: Diverse skills and experience vital
text:
Engaging with industry partners to build real world issues and challenges into the curriculum is an important part of the process, Dawkins says, as is the university's extensive series of mentoring programs.

One recent success he cites is Victoria University's multicultural mentoring program, which links students from culturally diverse backgrounds with mentors from founding partner, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia.

The university and Commonwealth Bank have signed a partnership agreement to expand the program this year following a pilot in 2017 involving 18 students.

"People who have already achieved success out in the real world, in the banking sector, can provide a lot of helpful guidance to our students, particularly around what we call the '21st-century skills,' around teamwork and creativity and problem-solving and communication skills," Dawkins says.

Diversity is key

The program builds on the extensive mentoring already offered by the university, he says, and was inspired by the diversity of the student population, and the community of which it is a part in the west of Melbourne.

"We see cultural diversity as one of the great strengths of the university and it's one of the key features of businesses being successful in the 21st century – being able to be across cultural understanding and to leverage off cultural diversity. We are in a position to offer businesses that benefit, in terms of our graduates."

The program is open to students who are coming towards the end of their studies at the university, regardless of whether they have a clear career goal or aim to work towards developing their goals through their involvement.

Advertisement

As they progress, students can start to clarify their initial career direction through discussions with their mentor about skills: what skills are important in the mentor's history of work, and whether these align with the student's skill set. The aim is to identify the student's interests, and what that identification tells them about the type of work they might like to do.

"I don't think you can overestimate the value of one-on-one relationships in mentoring to help students answer really big questions about the transition to work," Dawkins says. "We need as many ways as possible to make sure that the education system aligns with the world of work; particularly for those students who come from diverse backgrounds, and who might be the first in their family to go to university."

Dawkins was speaking in the wake of a recent joint research study undertaken by Fairfax Media, publisher of The Australian Financial Review, in partnership with the Commonwealth Bank that examined ways in which innovation can underpin the nation's economic future.

The survey of Financial Review readers found in terms of education, 62 per cent want greater integration between the private sector and education providers through programs such as these, 55 per cent want an increased emphasis on practical, vocational and technical training and 47 per cent want more initiatives encouraging women and girls in STEM careers.
description: Australian universities need to provide students with more of a balance between theory and practice to better integrate graduates with industry.
